title: NRZ-L (Non-Return-to-Zero Level)
description: NRZ-L is a binary encoding technique where a '1' is represented by a high signal and a '0' is represented by a low signal. The signal does not return to a neutral (zero) state between bits, hence the name.

title: NRZ-I (Non-Return-to-Zero Inverted)
description: In NRZ-I, a transition occurs at the beginning of a bit interval to represent a '1', while a '0' is represented by no transition. This technique helps reduce the DC component of the signal.

title: Bipolar AMI (Alternate Mark Inversion)
description: Bipolar AMI uses three levels: positive, negative, and zero. A '1' is represented by alternating between positive and negative voltages, while a '0' is represented by zero voltage.

title: Pseudoternary
description: Pseudoternary is a line coding scheme where a '0' is represented by a positive or negative pulse, and a '1' is represented by no pulse. It is similar to bipolar coding.

title: Manchester Encoding
description: Manchester encoding combines clock and data signals. A '0' is represented by a high-to-low transition, while a '1' is represented by a low-to-high transition. This provides a self-clocking feature.

title: Differential Manchester
description: Differential Manchester encoding is similar to Manchester encoding, but it uses transitions to indicate the start of a bit. A '1' is indicated by a transition at the beginning of the bit period, while a '0' is indicated by no transition.
